metadata.titleEn: The Datasets of the SRTM C/X-Band Radar Penetration Depth Differences on 1°×1° grid of High Mountain Asia Glaciers (2000)
metadata.description: Radar penetration correction is essential for accurately estimating glacier mass balance when using the geodetic methods based on the radar-derived Digital Elevation Model (DEM). Due to heterogeneous snow distribution and snowpack properties, the radar penetration depth varies by region and is basically dependent on the altitudes. Therefore, this data set gives the result of the penetration depth difference of SRTM C/X-band radar on 1°×1° grid of High Mountain Asia Glaciers. The data set contains 214 1°×1° grids SRTM X-band and C-band penetration depth difference in HMA, and a linear fitting expression for each grid. According to the geodetic method, the 30 m SRTM X-band and C-band DEM are used to obtain the results of the penetration depth difference between the SRTM X-band and C-band of the 1°×1° high grid in HMA, and obtain the relationship between the SRTM X-C-band penetration depth difference and the elevation in the glacier area (for specific methods, please refer to references). The data is stored in excel files. Observational data can provide important basic data for studying the glacier mass balance in HMA, and can be used by scientific researchers studying climate, hydrology and glaciers.
metadata.instructions: The file name is “SRTM C-X Penetration depth difference.xlsx”; The data is stored in Excel file, and the name of the behavior grid is listed as the corresponding penetration depth element. NAME，LON，LAT，PENETRATION，NMAD，LINE MODEL(X REPRESENTS ELEVATION AND Y REPRESENTS C-X RADAR PENETRATION DEPTH)，COEFFICIENT OF DETERMINATION®，RESIDUAL，P VALUE，ZMIN，ZMAX，NUM，SLOPE ERROR，INTERCEPT ERROR are grid name, longitude, latitude and SRTM respectively X-band and C-band penetration depth difference, uncertainty of penetration depth difference, linear fitting model, determination coefficient R, fitting residual, P value, minimum elevation, maximum elevation, fitting pixel number, slope error, intercept error.

background: The geodetic method is an established remote sensing method for estimating large-scale glacier mass balance, which is primarily based on the differencing of digital elevation models (DEMs) or altimetry data acquired in two or more epochs. The 30-m freely available Space Shuttle Radar Topographic Mission (SRTM) DEM, simultaneously acquired in February 2000 by C-band and X-band synthetic aperture radar (SAR) sensors, is one of the most widely used elevation data for regional glacier mass balance studies due to its wide coverage, high accuracy, and easy access. Radar with different wavelengths has different penetration depth into ice and snow due to radar volume scattering, in which microwaves interact with snow/ice through absorption, scattering, and refraction. In general, radar signals can penetrate several meters into ice and snow. Comparing the SRTM C/X-band DEMs on glacial areas was a common method to estimate the penetration depth into the snow of the SRTM C-band radar under the assumption of negligible X-band penetration. This method has been widely utilized to correct the penetration bias of SRTM C-band radar when estimating geodetic mass balance in HMA.
research objective: This study aims to estimate the penetration depth difference (hereafter referred to as PDD) of the C-band and X-band radar signals on the full-coverage HMA glaciers by exploiting SRTM C/X-band DEM products and evaluate the PDD altitude-dependency at different spatial scales.
challenges: However, the characteristics of spatial distribution and altitude dependence of the SRTM C/X-band penetration depth difference into the snow/ice of the entire HMA are still not very clear.
methods: First, coordinate system transformation and robust coregistration for SRTM C/X-band DEMs were performed. Further, we exploited the difference between the co-registered SRTM DEMs to obtain the penetration depth variation of the C/X-band radar signals. Finally, the spatial variability and altitude dependence of the PDD of 1° × 1° grid and 15 sub-regions in the HMA areas were analyzed.
dataset: The SRTM C-band and X-band DEMs were utilized to estimate the penetration difference of C/X-band radar into snow and ice in the study. The SRTM DEMs were generated by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the National Geospatial Intelligence Agency and the German Aerospace Center. The radar-based DEMs were acquired from February 11 to 22, 2000, covering approximately 80% of the total land area (60°S–60°N). We used a void-filled version of 1-arc-second C-band and X-band SRTM DEMs, which were freely downloaded from the EarthExplorer website and the EOWEB-NG website, respectively. The C-band and X-band SRTM DEMs have the same horizontal reference (WGS84 datum); however, the DEMs have a different vertical reference (the C-band is the EGM96 geoid, and the X-band is the WGS84 ellipsoid), which requires an elevation reference transformation.
findings: The results show that the difference of the SRTM C/X-band penetration depth in the HMA region is between −1.67 ± 0.65 m and 7.63 ± 0.99 m, with an average value of 2.40 ±0.04 m. A significant linear positive correlation between elevation and the PDD was found in most of 1° × 1° grid regions in HMA.

Definition.Question: What does 'penetration depth difference' mean in the context of radar signals for glacier studies?
Definition.Answer: In the context of radar signals for glacier studies, 'penetration depth difference' refers to the variance in the depth to which different radar wavelengths, specifically the C-band and X-band, penetrate ice and snow. This difference is crucial for accurately estimating glacier mass balance using digital elevation models (DEMs) as radar signals can penetrate several meters into ice and snow, affecting the elevation data.

Definition.Question: What does 'altitude-dependency' mean when analyzing penetration depth differences in radar data?
Definition.Answer: In the analysis of penetration depth differences in radar data, 'altitude-dependency' refers to the relationship between the penetration depth difference of radar signals and the elevation at which they are measured. This concept is important for understanding how penetration varies with altitude and for ensuring accurate corrections in geodetic mass balance estimations.

Comparison.Question: How does the method of estimating penetration depth difference using SRTM C/X-band DEMs compare to other geodetic methods in terms of accuracy for glacier mass balance studies?
Comparison.Answer: The geodetic method using SRTM C/X-band DEMs is an established remote sensing approach for estimating glacier mass balance. It is primarily based on differencing DEMs or altimetry data from different epochs. The method is widely used due to its wide coverage, high accuracy, and easy access. It offers a common technique for estimating penetration depth differences by comparing C-band and X-band DEMs, assuming negligible X-band penetration, which aids in correcting penetration bias.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when collecting SRTM C/X-band radar data for penetration depth analysis versus traditional field-based glacier data collection methods?
Comparison.Answer: The challenges in collecting SRTM C/X-band radar data include understanding the spatial distribution and altitude dependence of penetration depth differences, which are not very clear for the entire region. In contrast, traditional field-based methods might face logistical and environmental challenges but have direct interaction with the glacier surface, potentially offering different insights into ice and snow properties.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the spatial variability and altitude dependence of penetration depth differences in SRTM C/X-band radar data differ across various grid sizes and regions?
Comparison.Answer: The spatial variability and altitude dependence of penetration depth differences in SRTM C/X-band radar data are analyzed using 1° × 1° grid and 15 sub-regions. A significant linear positive correlation between elevation and the penetration depth difference was found in most grid regions, indicating that these factors may vary significantly across different spatial scales and regions.

Interpretation.Question: How does the method of coordinate system transformation and robust coregistration impact the accuracy of radar signal penetration depth estimation in glacier studies?
Interpretation.Answer: Coordinate system transformation and robust coregistration are crucial for aligning the SRTM C/X-band DEMs accurately, which is essential for reliable estimation of radar signal penetration depth. These steps ensure that the differences observed in DEMs are due to actual penetration depth variations rather than misalignments or errors in data processing.

Interpretation.Question: What underlying patterns can be identified from the penetration depth difference of C/X-band radar signals that would suggest a relationship with elevation across different spatial scales?
Interpretation.Answer: The penetration depth difference of C/X-band radar signals shows a significant linear positive correlation with elevation in many regions, indicating that as elevation increases, the penetration depth difference tends to increase. This pattern suggests that elevation is a key factor affecting radar penetration depth and should be considered when analyzing radar data for glacier studies.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the variability in radar penetration depth across different regions and altitudes in high mountainous areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The variability in radar penetration depth across different regions and altitudes is influenced by uneven snow distribution and varying snow properties, as the penetration depth of radar can vary depending on the region and is altitude-dependent.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it essential to understand the penetration depth difference when using radar-based digital elevation models for glacier mass balance studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Understanding the penetration depth difference is crucial because it helps in correcting the penetration bias of radar when estimating geodetic mass balance, which is vital for accurate glacier mass balance studies using radar-based digital elevation models.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in identifying the spatial distribution and altitude dependence of radar penetration depth differences in high mountainous areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in identifying the spatial distribution and altitude dependence of radar penetration depth differences arise due to the unclear characteristics of these factors across the entire region, necessitating coordinated efforts in data processing and analysis.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to understand the spatial distribution and altitude dependence of radar penetration depth differences in high mountain glacier regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The characteristics of spatial distribution and altitude dependence of the SRTM C/X-band penetration depth difference into the snow/ice of the entire HMA are still not very clear, and understanding these factors is crucial for correcting the penetration bias of SRTM C-band radar when estimating geodetic mass balance in HMA.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the intended purpose of using coordinate system transformation and robust coregistration in the processing of DEM data for glacier studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Coordinate system transformation and robust coregistration are performed to accurately align the SRTM C/X-band DEMs, which is essential for obtaining the penetration depth variation of the C/X-band radar signals and analyzing the spatial variability and altitude dependence of the PDD in HMA areas.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What specific procedures were employed to estimate the radar penetration depth difference between C-band and X-band signals in high-altitude glaciers?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To estimate the radar penetration depth difference between C-band and X-band signals, coordinate system transformation and robust coregistration for SRTM C/X-band DEMs were performed. The difference between the co-registered DEMs was then exploited to obtain the penetration depth variation. The spatial variability and altitude dependence of the penetration depth difference were analyzed across different spatial scales.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How does the elevation reference transformation process work when using C-band and X-band SRTM DEMs for estimating glacier mass balance?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The elevation reference transformation process involves converting the vertical references of the C-band and X-band SRTM DEMs. The C-band is referenced to the EGM96 geoid, while the X-band is referenced to the WGS84 ellipsoid. This difference necessitates an elevation reference transformation to align the DEMs for accurate estimation of glacier mass balance.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the accurate estimation of glacier mass balance using radar-based DEMs?
Enablement.Answer: The development and utilization of the 30-m freely available SRTM DEMs, acquired by C-band and X-band synthetic aperture radar sensors, enable the accurate estimation of glacier mass balance due to their wide coverage, high accuracy, and easy access. These DEMs allow for the comparison of penetration depths of radar signals into snow and ice, which is crucial for estimating glacier mass balance.

Enablement.Question: How do different radar wavelengths contribute to the understanding of radar penetration depth differences in glacial areas?
Enablement.Answer: Different radar wavelengths, such as C-band and X-band, have varying penetration depths into ice and snow due to radar volume scattering, as microwaves interact with snow/ice through absorption, scattering, and refraction. By comparing the SRTM C/X-band DEMs, researchers can estimate the penetration depth differences, aiding in correcting biases and improving the accuracy of glacier mass balance estimations.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods are essential for evaluating the altitude dependency of radar penetration depth differences in glacial regions?
Enablement.Answer: To evaluate the altitude dependency of radar penetration depth differences, coregistered SRTM C/X-band DEMs are used, and the spatial variability and altitude dependence are analyzed across 1° × 1° grid regions and sub-regions. These methods involve robust coordinate transformations and the exploitation of DEM differences to assess penetration depth variation effectively.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be a challenge in clearly understanding the spatial distribution and altitude dependence of radar penetration depths into snow/ice across the entire High Mountain Asia region?
Expectation.Answer: The characteristics of spatial distribution and altitude dependence of the SRTM C/X-band penetration depth difference into the snow/ice of the entire High Mountain Asia are still not very clear, which could be due to the complex nature of snow distribution and varying snow properties across different altitudes.

Expectation.Question: What could be the reason for performing coordinate system transformation and robust coregistration when using DEMs to analyze radar penetration depths?
Expectation.Answer: Coordinate system transformation and robust coregistration for SRTM C/X-band DEMs were performed to ensure accurate alignment and comparison of the datasets, which is crucial for effectively analyzing the penetration depth variation of the C/X-band radar signals.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in ensuring the accuracy of datasets used for estimating glacier mass balance using radar-based DEMs?
Judgmental.Answer: Ensuring dataset accuracy for glacier mass balance estimation is challenged by the need for precise coordinate system transformation and coregistration of DEMs, as well as addressing the different vertical references of C-band and X-band DEMs, which require elevation reference transformation.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could the current approach to data collection be refined to better understand the spatial variability of radar penetration depths?
Judgmental.Answer: The current approach could be refined by focusing on more detailed spatial analyses, such as exploring finer grid resolutions or incorporating additional data sources to complement the SRTM C/X-band DEMs, which would enhance understanding of spatial variability in radar penetration depths.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the radar penetration depth differences can vary with altitude in glacier studies.
Assertion.Answer: The penetration depth differences of the C-band and X-band radar signals vary with altitude due to the radar's interaction with snow and ice, which involves absorption, scattering, and refraction. The SRTM C/X-band DEMs are used to analyze these differences, revealing a significant linear positive correlation between elevation and penetration depth difference in many regions.

Assertion.Question: I don't see how the spatial distribution characteristics of radar penetration depth differences are determined in high mountain areas.
Assertion.Answer: The spatial distribution characteristics of radar penetration depth differences in high mountain areas are determined by exploiting the difference between co-registered SRTM C/X-band DEMs. This approach analyzes the penetration depth variation and assesses the spatial variability and altitude dependence in 1° × 1° grid regions and 15 sub-regions.

Assertion.Question: I can't figure out why it is necessary to correct the penetration bias of radar signals for glacier mass balance studies.
Assertion.Answer: Correcting the penetration bias of radar signals is crucial for glacier mass balance studies because different radar wavelengths penetrate ice and snow to varying depths. This penetration difference affects the accuracy of digital elevation models (DEMs), which are used in geodetic methods to estimate glacier mass balance. Proper corrections ensure more accurate estimations of glacier mass changes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges associated with obtaining accurate penetration depth differences of radar signals in glacial areas and propose potential solutions for overcoming these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges include understanding the spatial distribution and altitude dependence of the penetration depth differences of SRTM C/X-band radar signals in snow/ice across the entire HMA. These challenges arise due to variations in snow distribution and properties, affecting radar penetration depth. Potential solutions may involve conducting detailed spatial variability analyses and applying altitude-dependent corrections using robust data processing methods such as coordinate system transformation and coregistration of DEMs.

Request/Directive.Question: Please propose potential strategies for developing or enhancing datasets related to radar penetration depth differences in glacier studies.
Request/Directive.Answer: Strategies for enhancing datasets may include increasing spatial resolution by subdividing existing grids, integrating additional radar data from other missions, and employing advanced data processing techniques like machine learning for pattern recognition. Collaborating with international agencies to access more refined DEMs and expanding the temporal range of data collection could also improve dataset quality. Furthermore, refining the methods of altitude-dependency analysis can yield more accurate datasets.
